blocks.content: 1.2 Web Components: Frontend / Backend / Database / Hosting
A website is not just what you see on the screen. Behind the scenes, several parts work together. Let’s use an **online bookstore** as an example to explain the four main components.
The frontend is what you see when you open a website, such as the book list, shopping cart button, or login form.

items: 🔑 **Main Role**: Display content and provide interactions (e.g., clicking “Add to Cart”).
🎨 **Analogy**: Like the store’s storefront and decorations – the first thing customers see.

blocks.content: When you click a button on the frontend, such as “Checkout,” the backend handles the logic behind it.

items: 🔑 **Main Role**: Process user requests (e.g., calculate the total price, verify login).
🍳 **Analogy**: Like a restaurant kitchen – the frontend takes the order, the backend cooks the meal.

blocks.content: Every bookstore needs a place to record books and customer data. That’s the role of the database.

items: 🔑 **Main Role**: Store and manage information (e.g., book titles, prices, customer orders).
📦 **Analogy**: Like a warehouse where all the goods and records are stored.

blocks.content: Hosting means putting your website on the Internet so that anyone can visit your online bookstore anytime.

items: 🔑 **Main Role**: Keep the website online 24/7 and handle visitor traffic.
📚 **Platforms**: Free – GitHub Pages, Netlify; Professional – AWS, Vercel.
🌍 **Analogy**: Like renting a shop space on the street so everyone can enter.

blocks.content:
Here is a simple flow you can visualize as a diagram:

User → Frontend (browser view) → Backend (logic processing) → Database (read/store data) → Hosting (public Internet service) → Response back to user

blocks.title: 📖 Quick Summary
blocks.content:
👉 Frontend: The part users see
👉 Backend: The logic and actions behind the scenes
👉 Database: Stores all information
👉 Hosting: Publishes the site online

All four parts work together – like an online bookstore:
User selects a book (Frontend) → System calculates price (Backend) → Check book info (Database) → Make it available online for purchase (Hosting).
